bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 21, 1942

div1.p: Kean sends Hench a copy of a letter he sent to Harold W. Jones, congratulates Hench on finding additional letters from Lazear, and mentions Andrus' book.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, February 21, 1942
div1.opener:
2804 N St. n.w.
Washington, D.C.
Feb. 21, 1942
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Col. Harold W. Jones M. C. the Librarian
of the Army Medical Library has sent me a
copy of the reply that he sent you to your letter
to him with your letter. He was a very able surgeon.
I think probably the best in the Medical Corps &
was the Chief Surgeon at Hawaii, when some
years ago the Surgeon General brought him here
to be the Head of this great Library. Great Surgeons
are, like Horace described parts to be, an irritable
genus and Col. Jones is not an exception, as I
think you can see from his letter. I would not
waste any time on him if I were you. I inclose
a copy of my reply to him, which Mrs. Kean has
been kind enough to copy for me. In the very
brief note which I sent you while I was in
the hospital, I do not think I congratulated you
on your find - the file of letters from Dr. Lazear to his
mother covering the time he spent in Cuba.
This is I should think a discovery of the first order,
which will aid you immensely in your study
of his character. You have already come. I think,
to the conclusion that Lazear is entitled to stand
with Reed on a plane above Carroll & Agramonte
AC
K
2
and you will, I hope, have the material in hand
to make this clear to all the readers of your book.
I have a letter from Andrus saying that he
has determined not to try to find a publisher
for his Tale of a Guinea Pig until the war is
over. I think this is wise. It is surprising how,
while a war is on, people lose all interest in other
matters and even the best book has no chance
at all. Then a couple of years after the war
they will not look at a war book and the pendu-
lum swings back to normal. I hope that you
will continue your researches and be in no hurry
to finish your book until the gaps are looked &
the clouds of war roll by.

I feel much better, but my bladder is still
irritable and I have a feeling that I am not
well, altho. the very capable G. U. man at Walter Reed
tells me, to my great contentment of mind, that I have
no stone in the bladder nor a seriously enlarged
prostate, nor any residual urine. I go into these
details because you have showed so many
evidences of kindly and friendly interest in me

closer.seg:
P.S. You will find nothing in my letter to Jones which
you do not know already, but he is evidently badly
in need of orientation.
